title: Is it bad practice to take the premise of another short story? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ideas are worthless. The value of a story is in the execution. As long as you take the premise of the story and put your own spin on the execution, that’s called writing. Think about how every science fiction or fantasy TV series in recent years has a few “staple” episodes. The “body swap”, the “it was a dream/psychosis all along”, the “time loop”, the “evil twin”, the “everyone lost the last few days” amnesia. The premise gets recycled over and over again, but each show executes it differently. My writing group used to do a short story challenge every quarter. We would each take a prompt and write a story based on that prompt. Sometimes, we would draw lines out of a hat, or play a game to give everyone a unique starting point, but usually it was a picture, song, phrase or premise that we all started with and had to write a short story on. With 8–10 speculative fiction writers, we never saw two duplicate stories. We never saw two similar stories. We would start with “It’s a holiday morning and an unexpected gift shows up,” and get a frazzled mom with a baby fox, an alien on a spaceship trying to date a human, and a dead man trying to communicate with his mourning girlfriend. Don’t worry so much about the source of your ideas - worry about how you write them.

Short answer: No. … as long as you create a unique story from that premise. There are relatively few story premises, despite the millions of stories out there. It’s your twist on that premise, using your own characters, in situations you develop, that will make it different. How well you do that will determine what others think of it. If you just change the names but keep the same situations and outcome, then you’re ripping off someone else’s story—not their premise.
